message_1:
A student is studying complex analysis of Laplace transforms and needs to solve the following problem:

Use complex analysis techniques to evaluate the Laplace transform of the function f(t) = 2te^(3t)sin(4t) for t > 0.

Note: The Laplace transform of a function f(t) is defined as F(s) = ∫[0 to ∞] e^(-st)f(t)dt.
message_2:
To find the Laplace transform of the given function f(t) = 2te^(3t)sin(4t), we will use the definition of the Laplace transform:

F(s) = ∫[0 to ∞] e^(-st)f(t)dt

In this case, f(t) = 2te^(3t)sin(4t). So, we have:

F(s) = ∫[0 to ∞] e^(-st)2te^(3t)sin(4t)dt

Now, combine the exponential terms:

F(s) = ∫[0 to ∞] 2te^((3-s)t)sin(4t)dt

To solve this integral, we will use integration by parts. Let:

u = 2t, dv = e^((3-s)t)sin(4t)dt
du = 2dt, v = ∫ e^((3-s)t)sin(4t)dt

To find v, we will use integration by parts again. Let:

u1 = sin(4t), dv1 = e^((3-s)t)dt
du1 = 4cos(4t)dt, v1 = ∫ e^((3-s)t)dt = (1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)

Now, using integration by parts for v:

v = u1v1 - ∫v1du1 = sin(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t) - ∫(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)4cos(4t)dt

Let's call the remaining integral I:

I = ∫(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)4cos(4t)dt

Now, we can use integration by parts again for I:

u2 = cos(4t), dv2 = (1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)dt
du2 = -4sin(4t)dt, v2 = (1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)

Now, using integration by parts for I:

I = u2v2 - ∫v2du2 = cos(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t) + 4∫(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t)dt

Notice that the remaining integral is the same as the integral for v. So, we have:

I = cos(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t) + 4v

Now, we can substitute v back into the original integration by parts formula:

F(s) = uv - ∫vdu = 2t(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t) - ∫(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)4cos(4t)dt
F(s) = 2t(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t) - I

Substitute I back into the equation:

F(s) = 2t(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t) - (cos(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t) + 4v)

Now, substitute v back into the equation:

F(s) = 2t(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t) - (cos(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t) + 4(sin(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t) - ∫(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)4cos(4t)dt))

Now, we can combine terms and simplify:

F(s) = (2t(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t) - 4t(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t)sin(4t) + 4cos(4t)(1/(3-s))e^((3-s)t))/(1 + 4(1/(3-s))^2)

F(s) = (2(3-s)e^((3-s)t)(sin(4t) - 2tcos(4t)))/(s^2 - 6s + 25)

This is the Laplace transform of the given function f(t) = 2te^(3t)sin(4t).
